alert.note: Alert for Chelan (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued May 18 at 6:17PM PDT until May 18 at 8:15PM PDT by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE IRVING PEAK BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 815 PM PDT THIS EVENING FOR WEST CENTRAL CHELAN COUNTY... At 617 PM PDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Irving Peak Burn Scar. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will result in debris flow moving through the Little Wenatchee River Drainage. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding caused by thunderstorms in and around the Irving Peak Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Irving Peak Burn Scar. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Riverside Campground and Lake Creek Campground. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: The affected areas are in and below the Irving Peak burn scar northwest of Lake Wenatchee, including the steep slopes of along White River and Little Wenatchee River. High intensity rainfall on the burned area may cause flash flooding, mud slides and rock slides. Hikers, campers, and motorists in and below the Irving Peak burned area should take immediate precautions to protect life and property. Move away from recently burned areas. Life-threatening flooding of creeks, roads and normally dry arroyos is likely. The heavy rains will likely trigger rockslides, mudslides and debris flows in steep terrain, especially in and around these areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
